data.title: KU School of Business celebrates International Women’s Day
data.meta_description: KU Provost and Executive Vice Chancellor Neeli Bendapudi is a KU business alumna. She was the first woman to serve as dean of the School of Business. In July 2017, L. Paige Fields began her tenure as…
data.text:
KU Provost and Executive Vice Chancellor Neeli Bendapudi is a KU business alumna. She was the first woman to serve as dean of the School of Business.

In July 2017, L. Paige Fields began her tenure as the Henry D. Price professor and dean of the School of Business.

Our alumnae are leaders in higher education, business and government.

Alumnae Erica LeBlanc, global brand director for S.C. Johnson, and Rekha Patnaik, executive vice president and director of bank strategy and administration for UMB Bank, received our 2017 Emerging Leader Award.

Alumna Jesse Hufft is co-founder and CEO of Hufft Projects, a Kansas City-based architecture firm.

In 2015, alumna and PR powerhouse Roshann Parris received the B-school’s distinguished alumni award. Parris is the president and CEO of Parris Communications.

MBA alumna Jill Docking ran for election to the office of lieutenant governor on Paul Davis’ 2014 Kansas gubernatorial ticket. She is the also former chair of the Kansas Board of Regents and, in 1993, became the first woman to receive the gubernatorial appointment as the Commanding General of the Kansas Cavalry.

MBA alumna and dean’s advisory board member Margo Shepherd was named a top financial advisor by Financial Times in 2015.

Doctoral alumna Ilene Kleinsorge was honored for her tenure as dean at Oregon State University’s College of Business in 2015.

Accounting alumna and past chair of the school’s Dean’s Board of Advisors Diane Yetter was elected to KU Endowment’s board of trustees in 2015. She serves as president of Yetter Consulting Services and is founder of the Sales Tax Institute. Yetter was recognized as one of Accounting Today’s 2017 “100 Most Influential People in Accounting.

Devenie Ross, who received her bachelor’s in accounting from KU in 2015 and graduated with a Master of Accounting in 2016, was one of the winners of the American Institute of CPAs’ 2016 Elijah Watt Sells Award.

KU business faculty make major contributions to their respective fields, and the KU B-school attracts top minds from across the country and world.

Amii Castle, a lecturer in the Schools of Business and Law, received the 2017 H.O.P.E. Award. The recognition — to Honor an Outstanding Progressive Educator — is given annually by the senior class through the Board of Class Officers.

In spring 2018, professor of accounting and Porter Faculty Fellow Susan Scholz was announced as the school’s new executive associate dean.

Staff make everything possible, and our B-school women continue to make waves in their work.

In 2015, the MBA program’s long-time director, Dee Steinle, was appointed to executive director of MBA and MSB programs.

Career advisor Ashley Kruger was named as one of the 2015–2016 KU Women of Distinction.

As you can see, KU women truly run the world.

Bernadette Gray-Little, KU’s 17th chancellor, holds the distinction of being the first female and first African-American chancellor in KU history.

Happy International Women’s Day to our alumnae, students, faculty and staff.

This was originally posted March 8, 2016, and was updated March 7, 2018.
